text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 8.21.2, Account and Processing Support(APS) Statute Responsibility.
IRM 8.21.2.1, Program Scope and Objectives and related subsections were added.
) IRM
added TBOR content based on guidance from the Division Counsel/Associate Chief Counsel (National Taxpayer Advocate Program) and Branch
of the Associate Chief Counsel (Procedure and Administration). (
) IRM
updated instruction on how to download Tackon ACDS software. (
) Updated references and links throughout.
IRM 8.21.2.6.1 updated instruction on how to download Tackon ACDS software.
Updated references and links throughout.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS
IRM 8.21.2, Appeals Statute Responsibility - Account and Processing Support (APS) Statute Responsibility, dated October 15, 2014, is superseded.
Account and Processing Support (APS) Statute Responsibility
Table of Contents
Program Scope and Objectives
Account and Processing Support (APS) Statute Responsibility 8.21.2
Scope and (
) Purpose: This IRM section describes the statute responsibilities for APS Employees. Speciﬁcally IRM

provides instruction on: a. The statute responsibilities for APS employees; b. When APS is responsible for the statute; c. Veriﬁcation of statutes and assessments/abatements; d. Updating statutes on ACDS and AIMS; and e. Statute actions on cases when a Statutory Notice of Determination is issued. (
) Audience: APS Employees, Managers, and Technical Advisors (
) Policy Owner: Policy, Planning, Quality and Analysis is under the Director Case and Operations Support. (

) Program Owner: Appeals Policy is the program office responsible for providing technical and procedural guidance to the Appeals organization and is under the Director of Policy, Planning, Quality and Analysis. (

) Contact Information: Appeals employees should follow established procedures on How to Contact an Analyst . Other employees should contact the Product Content Owner shown on the Product Catalog Information Page for this (
) The Policy analyst shown on the Product Catalog page as the originator is assigned author of this IRM. Reports (
) Policy, Planning, Quality, and Analysis (PPQA) provides trend and data analyses and detailed summary reports for Appeals. and Acronyms (
) See IRM
, Common Terms Used in Appeals, for common terms and deﬁnitions used in IRM Part
Terms listed in this exhibit are not included this section. Resources (
) The Taxpayer Bill of Rights (TBOR) lists rights that already existed in the code, putting them in simple language and grouping them into
fundamental rights. Employees are responsible for being familiar with and acting in accord with taxpayer rights. See IRC
), Execution of Duties in Accord Taxpayer Rights. For additional information about the TBOR, see https://www. irs.gov/taxpayer-bill-of-rights . Guidelines for and Processing (APS) (

) Account and Processing Support (APS) employees include the following positions: a. Processing Team Manager (PTM) b. Tax Examining Technicians (TE) c. Any other Appeals employee doing processing work similar to the TE (
) IRM
is the primary source of reference used by APS employees when verifying, updating, and monitoring statute dates on Appeals’ cases. Responsibility
A (
) Internal Revenue Manual
Purpose: This IRM section describes the statute responsibilities for APS Employees. Speciﬁcally IRM 8.21.2 provides instruction on:

The statute responsibilities for APS employees; When APS is responsible for the statute; Veriﬁcation of statutes and assessments/abatements; Updating statutes on ACDS and AIMS; and Statute actions on cases when a Statutory Notice of Determination is issued.
The Policy analyst shown on the Product Catalog page as the originator is the assigned author of this IRM.
Policy, Planning, Quality, and Analysis (PPQA) provides trend and data analyses and detailed summary reports for Appeals.
See IRM 8.1.1-1, Common Terms Used in Appeals, for common terms and deﬁnitions used in IRM Part 8. Terms listed in this exhibit are not included in
IRM 8.21 is the primary source of reference used by APS employees when verifying, updating, and monitoring statute dates on Appeals’ cases.
8.21 Appeals Statute Responsibility

) APS is responsible for verifying and monitoring the statute dates on all tax periods or returns under its jurisdiction. APS has jurisdiction of the case under the following circumstances: a. Case is carded on Appeals Centralized Database System (ACDS) as being in APS possession b. Case ﬁle is date stamped “received” by APS but not yet carded on ACDS c. Case ﬁle is transmitted to another location but no acknowledgment is received from the intended recipient (

) To ensure that adequate statute control is maintained at all times while APS has jurisdiction of the case, APS will : a. Timely open incoming mail and verify statute dates on all new receipts, including cases transferred from another Appeals Office b. Keep ACDS current by timely updating ACDS for statute extensions and consents. c. Input new receipts and close cases off ACDS as soon as possible d. Issue Statutory Notices of Deﬁciency (SND) in a timely manner e. Immediately assign cases and returns when an assessment is required. The assigned APS employee will validate the assessment statute date upon receipt; f. Verify that Compliance-initiated assessments and abatements have been completed at the time the case is carded on ACDS g. Generate and process ACDS reports and follow-up lists as provided in IRM

h. Generate CASES on Processing Employees Automated System (PEAS) Inventory statute reports as outlined in this document i. Monitor Partnership Control System (PCS) reports generated from ACDS for cases that have Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act (TEFRA) linkages (

) Immediately upon assignment, APS will inspect all case ﬁles to verify the earliest statute date for each tax period and each type of tax contained in ﬁle. (
) APS will also verify that the statute dates reﬂected on the transmittal and/or AMDISA print are correct. (

) APS will never assume that the statute date on the transmittal and/or AMDISA print is correct. If the statute date on the Audit Information Management System (AIMS) is incorrect, update it to the correct date by using command code AMSTUB (positions

) If it is unclear which statute date applies, always use the earliest, most conser- vative date. Alert the PTM, Appeals Team Manager (ATM) and/or Appeals Technical Employee (ATE) assigned the case to the discrepancy. (
) Veriﬁcation of the statute date should include a review of all original, copy, formation, reference or substitute for return contained in the ﬁle. PTM/ATM must follow the AIVP validations. See IRM
for additional information. (
) Consider assessment and/or collection statute dates when verifying statute limitations on the following receipts: a. Docketed Cases b. Innocent Spouse Cases
) Immediately upon assignment, APS will inspect all case ﬁles to verify the earliest statute date for each tax period and each type of tax contained ﬁle. (
) APS will also verify that the statute dates reﬂected on the transmittal AMDISA print are correct. (

) APS will never assume that the statute date on the transmittal and/or print is correct. If the statute date on the Audit Information Management System (AIMS) is incorrect, update it to the correct date by using command code AMSTUB (positions

for additional (

c. Collection Due Process (CDP), Offer in Compromise (OIC), Trust Fund Recovery Penalty (TFRP), Penalty Appeals (PENAP) (
) Use the most recently executed consent (Form
-A, etc.) when deter- mining the statute date. etc. (
) Analyze the most recent consent (Form

-A, etc.) to verify that it: a. is properly executed, b. contains the correct taxpayer information, and c. covers all years and types of tax included in the work unit. Note: Although APS employees are not responsible for determining the validity prior consents as long as the current consent is valid , the validity of consents should be determined by the ATE assigned to the case. (

) If the current consent is not valid, the APS employee will need to verify the validity of the next prior consent. If valid, the statute date reﬂected on that consent will be used as the statute control date. (
) The above actions will be repeated until it can be determined that there is a valid statute on all the returns included in the work unit. (
) If a valid statute date cannot be determined, immediately seek assistance the PTM in determining what statute date to use. (
) If it is determined that a valid statute exists but there are less than
days remaining on the assessment statute, follow the procedures found in IRM
, Receiving Returns and Administrative Files and associated subsec- tions for additional information. See IRM
for exceptions. by in the (POA) (
) If an individual named in the POA, Form
, signs the consent, the TE verify that the POA is authorized to sign the consent for the tax period, type tax and taxpayer shown in the consent. See IRM

, Command Codes CFINK , RPINK, KAFFQ and KAFTQ for CAF Inquiry, for information regarding IDRS Command Code CFINK. a. If the POA form does not cover all periods, types of tax, etc. of the the APS Tax Examiner will make a notation in the NOTES ﬁeld on ACDS to alert the ATM and ATE of this fact. (

) If there is evidence that Compliance should have made an assessment or abatement, the APS Tax Examiner will request a current IDRS transcript Command Code TXMOD, IMFOL, BMFOL,etc.) to verify that the action was taken and follow these steps a. Highlight the assessment or abatement on the transcript b. Place the transcript in the case ﬁle (

) If there is evidence that Compliance should not have made an assessment abatement, the APS Tax Examiner will request a current IDRS transcript to verify the current status of the account. and Processing Support (APS) Statute

) If there is evidence that Compliance should have made an assessment or abatement, the APS Tax Examiner will request a current IDRS transcript (IDRS Command Code TXMOD, IMFOL, BMFOL,etc.) to verify that the action was taken and follow these steps a. Highlight the assessment or abatement on the transcript b. Place the transcript in the case ﬁle (
) If there is evidence that Compliance should not have made an assessment or abatement, the APS Tax Examiner will request a current IDRS transcript to verify the current status of the account.
8.21 Appeals Statute Responsibility

a. The APS Tax Examiner will notify the PTM who will verify with the ATM, ATE or the Counsel Attorney that the Compliance adjustment should remain or should be reversed. b. The PTM will secure written authority to adjust the account, when appro- priate, from the ATM, ATE or Counsel Attorney. c. The APS Tax Examiner will take action to process the approved account adjustment, using Form
if the case is established on the AIMS or Form
if the case is not established on AIMS. Refer to IRM
, Account and Processing Support, Closing Procedures.
) Special Situations (

) For innocent spouse cases, the APS TE must ﬁrst determine whether or not the amount at issue has been assessed in order to determine the appropriate statute date and code to input on ACDS for the requesting and non-requesting spouse. Refer to IRM
, Innocent Spouse Case Overview and related subsections for procedures for the receipt and control of Innocent Spouse cases.
) Cases Not Accepted by Appeals (
) There are several cases that Appeals will not accept, See IRM
, Cases Not Accepted by Appeals, for a listing of types of cases not accepted Appeals.
) Actions When Statute Date is Uncertain (

) Any new case received in APS where the correct statute date cannot be identi- ﬁed will be handled as a priority case and identiﬁed as a short statute case until the correct statute date is determined. Under no circumstances should case be held more than two (
) work days without action to resolve the statute date question. (

) If the APS Tax Examiner is unable to determine the correct statute date, imme- diately contact an ATM or other designated ATE located on-site. If there is no one who can provide on-site assistance, seek guidance from the PTM. (
) If for any reason the correct statute date still cannot be identiﬁed, continue carding process on ACDS, using the date of carding for the statute date. Enter STATUTE UNKNOWN in the notes ﬁeld. (

) Expeditiously send the case to the appropriate ATM for assignment. APS Tax Examiner will place the case in a red folder and mark an expedite tag to alert the receiver that the statute date is uncertain at this time. (
) The PTM will send an email with the WUNO to the APS Statute Policy Analyst/ IRM
Author - Refer to the Content POC on Product Catalog Informa- tion Page for IRM
) APS will use Form
, Document Transmittal, (or electronic Form
) for all case movement out of APS. Jurisdiction shifts from APS upon conﬁrmation of receipt (acknowledged
) by the ATM.
) Updating Statutes on ACDS and AIMS (
) Statute date and statute code must be updated on ACDS and AIMS in a timely manner. Timely is deﬁned as one (
) workday from the date of notiﬁcation or receipt of documentation. page

Account and Processing Support (APS) Statute Responsibility 8.21.2
) The following is a list of circumstances that affect the statute date, and will require an update to the statute date or statute code on ACDS and AIMS. Exhibit
for ACDS Statute Codes. a. For any statute expiring within
days, notify the manager listed on - Prompt, Quick, Jeopardy & Termination Assessments . b. Signed notice of termination of special consent (i.e., Forms
-Q, etc.). Enter a date of
days from when your office received notice OR

days from mailing a signed termination to the taxpayer if issued by the Service. c. Petition ﬁled with Tax Court. Eliminate the statute date and enter the ute code DOCKT. d. Petition ﬁled with Bankruptcy Court. Enter the statute code BKRUP; ever, the original statute date must also remain. In this instance you also update the Feature Code to BK. e. Defaulted notice of deﬁciency. Enter a date of
days (
for foreign country residents) from what the normal or extended statute date was before the statutory notice was issued. (Consent Forms
-R, are cancelled on the date the statutory notice was issued.) See IRM
, Adding Tack-On Time to Statutes. f. Agreement during the
-day period after a notice of deﬁciency. Enter date
days from the date the agreement is received in Appeals or the original statute date, whichever is later. See IRM
for procedures on tack-on time. g. Decision entered on a petitioned Tax Court case. Enter a date
days from what the normal or extended statute date was before the statutory notice was issued OR
days from the decision entered date, which- ever is later. Remove the statute code DOCKT. If less than
days re- main on the statute, compute the statute date using tack-on procedures. If you use a tack-on statute date, also input statute code FINAL. See
or procedures on tack-on time. h. Decision entered on docketed substitute for return (SFR). Compute the statute date: Decision Entered Date +
years +
days = the newly computed statute date. For example: entered date = March
+ three years = March
days = July
The newly computed statute date is July
For Non-Docketed SND defaults on SFR returns (and no delinquent return has been ﬁled/provided) – Compute the statute date: Default Date +
years. i. Stay lifted on assessment by Bankruptcy Court. Enter at least
days from the date the stay was lifted. (This determination should be made the Bankruptcy Coordinator or appeals officer.) j. Written request to update the statute date is received from the ATM or (
) APS Tax Examiners will use the standalone program Tacko
CDS.EXE to compute the tack-on statute date (
) Appeals will not use “Tack-On” time unless there is less than
days remaining on the statute. (
) “Tack-On” time is the number of days remaining on the statute date which is impacted by the issuance of a notice of deﬁciency or a tax court decision or order of dismissal being entered.
8.21 Appeals Statute Responsibility

) “Tack-on” time for defaulted notices of deﬁciency is computed as follows: date PLUS number of days from issue date to the normal or extended statute date before the notice of deﬁciency was issued. (
) If the tack-on statute date is used at ANY time, the statute code FINAL must be entered for every return impacted. The FINAL Tack-On statute must not used unless the normal statute date or
day default/entered statute has expired or sufficient time doesn’t allow for the case to be processed through IDRS. (
) Anytime the statute is updated using these procedures, the computations be approved by the PTM or Lead. A copy of the approved Tack-on computation must be uploaded to ACDS as an attachment. (
) To Obtain the Tack-On ACDS Software: a. For Windows

- Click on the Start button b. Navigate to the Symantec folder c. Click on Symantec Software Portal d. Scroll down on the list of applications until you reach Tackon ACDS. on the icon and follow the remaining prompts for installation. (
) Tack-On Time - Agreed Notice of Deﬁciency • The Tack-on statute date (
-Day Agreed statute) on an agreed notice of deﬁciency is the number of days that the statute was suspended
days. (
) Tack-On Time - Defaulted Notice of Deﬁciency • Defaulted Notice of Deﬁciency - The Tack-On statute date (
-Day Agreed Statute) on an agreed notice of deﬁciency is the number of that the statute was suspended plus
days. • NOTE: Exception to the above - If a notice of deﬁciency was issued on a case extended by an executed Form
-A, the default statute date is computed by adding
days plus
days to the date the notice of deﬁciency was issued. The statute date is not suspended indeﬁnitely. (
) Tack-On Time - Docketed Cases with Decisions Entered • The Tack-On statute date (Decision Entered Statute) on a docketed case with an entered decision is computed by adding
days (for decision to become ﬁnal) plus
days (for assessment) plus the sus- pension period (the period from the date of the notice of deﬁciency the normal or extended statute date).
Scroll down on the list of applications until you reach Tackon ACDS. Click on the icon and follow the remaining prompts for installation.
The Tack-on statute date (90-Day Agreed statute) on an agreed notice of deﬁciency is the number of days that the statute was suspended plus
APS is responsible for monitoring the statute date on any case sent outside the local Appeals office until an acknowledged
transmittal or other written conﬁrmation is received from the recipient office.
When transmitting unassigned non-docketed cases to Counsel for any reason, list all statute dates on the transmittal memorandum to Counsel.
Account and Processing Support (APS) Statute Responsibility 8.21.2
) Enter the earliest statute date on the front of the administrative ﬁle (Form or similar form) and on the transmittal. (

) Since APS is responsible for monitoring the statute of limitations until the knowledgement receipt is received, the APS Tax Examiner will follow-up by phone or secure email if the acknowledgement is not received within ten work days. Note: Acceptance of the ACDS inbox transfers by the receiving office transfers statute responsibility to that office. (
) If the acknowledgement is not received within
work-days, alert the PTM involvement. (
) Transferring cases with assessment periods expiring within
days should avoided. Cases with imminent statute dates should only be shipped under direction of the APS Area Manager. (
) When secure emailing or faxing a case, include the Taxpayer’s name, Taxpayer Identiﬁcation Number (TIN), tax periods and statute dates. (
) The receiving APS office will review all statute dates on the returns received ensure the correct dates are shown on ACDS and AIMS.
) Receipt of Consent Termination (Form
-T
) Receipt of a Form
-T, Notice of Termination of Special Consent to Extend the Time to Assess Tax Form, or Form
-N, Notice of Termination of Consent to Extend the Time to Assess Tax Attributable to Partnership Items, signed by, or on behalf of, the taxpayer, automatically decreases the statute date to
days from the receipt date of the form. (
) The actions taken will depend on whether the case is open or closed. This section details the procedures to follow when these forms are received on open and closed cases.
) Consent Termination on Cases Open in Appeals (
) When the APS receives a Form
-T or

-N signed by, or on behalf of, taxpayer is received the APS Tax Examiner will immediately research ACDS ﬁnd the assigned ATE. a. If the employee is on-site, hand-deliver the form. b. If off-site, immediately fax the form. Email the ATE to notify that the is being faxed. Mail the original soon after.
) Consent Termination on Cases Closed in Appeals (
) When a Form
-T or
-N is received on a case that has already closed Appeals, immediately check IDRS to determine if the tax year is open in another function. (
) If it is, contact that function by phone or email to alert them of receipt of the form. A copy should be faxed immediately and the original form mailed to other function using Form
, Document Transmittal. (
) Ensure that the other function acknowledges receipt by returning a copy of Form

) work days.
The receiving APS office will review all statute dates on the returns received to ensure the correct dates are shown on ACDS and AIMS.

8.21.2.9.1(10-15-2014) Undeliverables and Unclaimed Notices
If a Notice of Deﬁciency or Determination Letter is returned undelivered or unclaimed, follow the procedures in IRM 8.20.6.8.6.
The APS Tax Examiner will promptly notify the ATE when an agreement is received during the 90/150-suspense period after an SND is issued.
Request that the ATE assigned to the case determine if Appeals accepts the agreement. Update the statute date on ACDS and AIMS to the agreement date +
days. Prepare the case for closing following the procedure in IRM
) Statutory of Deﬁciency (
) The APS Tax Examiner will follow the procedures in IRM
when taxpayers petition the Tax Court after issuance of the SND. (

) If the taxpayer does not petition one or more years of a multi-year notice, APS Tax Examiner will update the statute date on ACDS and AIMS. The APS Tax Examiner will establish a new workunit on ACDS for the non-petitioned years to control the correct statute dates. See IRM
) of Cases for (

) The APS Tax Examiner is responsible for reviewing all cases received for closing. The review includes verifying the correct statute date and ensuring ACDS is promptly updated with the correct statute date. (
) The APS Tax Examiner will follow IRM
to process tried, dismissed or settled docketed cases. (
) Cases received in APS for closing will be date stamped by the APS Tax Examiners upon receipt. The date stamp on the case is the date the APS Examiner will enter on PEAS.
) Veriﬁcation on Closings (

) When a case is assigned for closing, the APS Tax Examiner will inspect the to determine the correct statute date for each tax period and each type of in the case. APS will use the most current extension (Form
-A, etc.) attached to the return. (
) The APS Tax Examiner will consult with the PTM if there is uncertainty about the correct statute date. (

) Cases not controlled on AIMS, such as Interim Action Requests, and cases controlled with an ASED statute date, such as Innocent Spouse cases, will also be reviewed by the APS Tax Examiner for assessment statute determina- tion. (
) The APS Tax Examiner will closely inspect the ﬁle to ensure that all documents requiring assessment (partial agreements, taxable amended returns, etc.) been properly processed. (
) Closings on Statute Cases (
) A case received with less than
days remaining on the assessment statute requires the APS Tax Examiner to prepare a manual assessment package including Form
, Request for Quick or Prompt Assessment, for submission to the Customer or Processing Campus. APS Tax Examiners will adhere to following timeframes: a. Cases with statute dates expiring in

) Prior to any known absence from the office, the APS Tax Examiner will notify the PTM of short statute cases needing action. Once notiﬁed, the PTM is sponsible for follow-up actions on the case during the APS Tax Examiner’s absence. Reject at (

) When a case sent for closing is missing or contains incorrect information, contact the ATE for clariﬁcation. It is important to remember that the jurisdiction of the case is with the APS Tax Examiner. (

) If a case is rejected and the tax periods have not been assessed/abated, APS Tax Examiner will not change the statute date information on ACDS. Leaving the original statute date on ACDS ensures the case will continue appear on the statute report. (
) The APS Tax Examiner will follow procedures in IRM
for updating statute date and statute code on ACDS for any rejected returns. (

) If the case is to be returned to the ATE, the APS Tax Examiner will note the earliest statute date on the front of the case ﬁle and ensure that the correct statute date is reﬂected on ACDS. The APS Tax Examiner will use Form to return the case to the ATE. Jurisdiction shifts to the ATE upon receipt of acknowledged Form

) The APS Tax Examiner will retain copies of all non-AIMS adjustments, such those input with IDRS Command Code REQ

) On a weekly basis, each APS Tax Examiner will generate their individual statute report, and note the status and actions taken or expected to be taken on the report. (
) The APS Tax Examiner will return this report to the PTM for review of the notes and veriﬁcation that the proper actions are being taken. (
) The individual statute reports for each APS Tax Examiner will be attached behind the monthly report for the entire group.
